0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Homocystinuria: 3 grams ORALLY twice daily, doses may be gradually increased until plasma homocysteine exists in small amounts or is undetectable

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Homocystinuria: (less than 3 y of age) 100 mg/kg/day, increase dose weekly by 100 mg/kg until plasma homocysteine exists in small amounts or is undetectable
  • Homocystinuria: (3 y and older) 3 grams ORALLY twice daily, doses may be gradually increased until plasma homocysteine exists in small amounts or is undetectable

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Systemic: Betaine acts as a methyl group donor in the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine in patients with homocystinuria. This reduces toxic concentrations of homocysteine, usually to 20 to 30% or less of pretreatment concentrations .
  • Betaine also has been shown to increase low plasma methionine and S-adenosylmethionine concentrations in patients with 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) deficiency and cobalamin cofactor metabolism (cbl) defect .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • (powder for solution) may be administered concomitantly with vitamin B6, vitamin B12 and folate
  • (powder for solution) measure with scoop provided; 1 level scoop (1.7 cc) = 1 gram betaine anhydrous powder
  • (powder for solution) dissolve in 4-6 ounces water, juice, milk, formula, or mix with food for immediate ingestion

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• plasma homocysteine level
  • plasma methionine concentrations; in patients with cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause diarrhea or nausea.
  • May be taken concomitantly with vitamin B6, vitamin B12, and folic acid.
